claim: If you watch a pot of water on the stove, it will boil.

supporting.text: Watching a pot of water does not affect the boiling process, as boiling is determined by heat transfer and temperature reaching 100°C (212°F) at standard pressure.

attacks.text: Watching a pot of water does not affect the boiling process, as boiling is determined by heat transfer and temperature reaching 100°C (212°F) at standard pressure.
Human observation can indirectly affect boiling time by adjusting the stove's heat output if the observer intervenes (e.g., lowering heat to prevent overflow).
Such interventions are rare in practice, as most people do not adjust heat during boiling unless explicitly monitoring for safety.
The claim implies psychological perception (e.g., 'a watched pot never boils'), suggesting subjective time distortion rather than physical causation.
Psychological time distortion is irrelevant to the physical process of boiling, which is objectively measurable.

supporting.text: Boiling water is a physical process dependent on heat energy, not observation, so the claim is false because watching it does not cause boiling.
